questions.question:
Question 1: A researcher is planning to study the etiology of certain painful idiopathic peripheral 
neuropathies. Which of the following study methods shall he choose?
questions.explanation: Diseases of unknown etiology or new diseases can be studied with descriptive epidemiology.

questions.question:
Question 2: The preliminary observations made by Burkitt in Africa eventually found that the 
Epstein-Barr Virus is an etiological factor for Burkitt lymphoma. What is this study an 
example of?
questions.explanation:
The given scenario is an example of a descriptive study. 86 
Sold by @itachibot Descriptive studies are used to describe a disease of unknown etiology. These studies also led to 
the discovery of prions as the etiological agents of chronic degenerative neurological disorders 
(Kuru) in humans. This is also an example of a descriptive study. Types of epidemiological studies: • Observational studies - allow nature to take its own course, the investigator measures but does 
not intervene. • Descriptive studies - limited to the description of the occurrence of a disease in a population. • Analytical studies - go further by analyzing the relationship between health status and other 
variables. • Ecological studies • Cross-sectional studies • Case-control studies • Cohort studies • Experimental studies or intervention studies involve an active attempt to change a disease 
determinant or the progress of a disease and are similar in design to experiments in other 
sciences. • Randomized controlled trials • Field trials • Community trials

questions.question: Question 3: Which of the following are included in descriptive epidemiology?
questions.explanation:
Descriptive epidemiology involves describing the disease in terms of time, place, and person 
distribution.

questions.question: Question 4: Which of the following best describes the term hypothesis?
questions.explanation:
An epidemiological hypothesis is a supposition or variable. It is arrived at from observation and 
needs to be tested. Descriptive studies primarily focus on the formulation of a hypothesis. Analytical studies which include study designs like case-control and cohort are used to test the 
formulated hypothesis. The hypothesis can subsequently be rejected or accepted. Experimental studies involve an intervention to provide scientific proof for etiological risk factors 
of diseases and to measure the efficiency of health services.

questions.question:
Question 5: The National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases is planning to study the natural 
history of COVID-19. Which of the following studies can be used?
questions.explanation:
87 
Sold by @itachibot Longitudinal studies are useful to study the natural history of a disease. It is also used to identify risk factors, and to find the incidence rate. In longitudinal studies, 
observations are repeated in the same population over a prolonged period of time by follow-up 
examinations. Their disadvantage is that they are difficult to organize and take a very long time.

questions.question: Question 6: What are prevalence studies also known as?
questions.explanation:
Cross-sectional studies help in obtaining the prevalence of a disease. Hence, they are also known 
as prevalence studies. Cross-sectional study is a type of observational study where a cross-section of a population is 
examined once at one point in time. It is more useful in studying chronic diseases than acute 
ones. They do not provide information on the natural history of disease or incidence and also do 
not establish the time sequence.

questions.question: Question 7: Which of the following statements about point source epidemic is false?

options.b: Clustering of cases occur within a short period of time
options.c: It occurs only due to an infectious agent
options.d: All cases usually develop within one incubation period

questions.explanation:
Point source epidemics are caused not only due to infectious agents but also by environmental 
pollution and contamination of food. Point source epidemics belong to the common source type of epidemics. Exposure to disease 
agents is brief so they are also called single exposure epidemics. All cases develop within one incubation period. In the epidemic curve, there is a sharp rise and 
fall as all cases are clustered within one incubation period. There are no secondary waves and 
these epidemics tend to be explosive.

questions.question:

questions.explanation:
Point-source epidemic is depicted in the given image. In the epidemic curve for a point-source epidemic, there is a sharp rise and fall of the curve with 
no secondary waves. It tends to be explosive as all the cases are clustered in a narrow period of 
time. It occurs within one incubation period of the disease.

questions.question:
Question 9: An outbreak of viral hepatitis A was reported from a town between June and September of a 
particular year. The peak of the outbreak occurred in July. What is this an example of?
questions.explanation:
This outbreak of viral hepatitis A is an example of a common source, multiple exposure type of 
epidemic. The incubation period of hepatitis A is approximately 28 days (range 15 to 50 days). In this 
scenario, the cases of viral hepatitis A have occurred over a period from June to September (120 
days) which is more than one incubation period of the disease. This is suggestive of multiple 88 
Sold by @itachibot exposures from a common source. If the period of the outbreak falls within one incubation period, then the type of epidemic is 
common source ,single exposure or point source epidemic. Difference between single exposure and multiple exposure epidemics: Propagated epidemic results from person to person transmission of the infectious agent over a 
prolonged duration of time. For e.g. Polio epidemic, COVID-19. Note: Hepatitis A epidemic is generally an example of a propagated epidemic. However, it does 
not always follow this pattern. In the given scenario, since the outbreak lasts for a short 
duration of 3 months (about 3 incubation periods for hepatitis A), it is considered to be a point 
source, multiple exposure outbreak. Common source, multiple ex

questions.question:
Question 10: The sales team of a corporate company presents to the hospital with complaints of sudden 
onset nausea, vomiting and loose stools. They give a history of having food from a nearby 
bakery three hours ago. What is this an example of?
questions.explanation:
The given scenario is suggestive of food poisoning. It is a type of common-source (point-source), 
single exposure epidemic.

questions.question: Question 11: Which of the following is an example of disease following a seasonal trend?

options.a: Occurrence of rubella every 6-9 years in the pre-vaccination era
options.b: Occurrence of influenza pandemic every 7-10 years
options.c: Occurrence of bacterial gastroenteritis in summer
options.d: Increase in the occurrence of diabetes in developed countries

questions.explanation:
Occurrence of bacterial gastroenteritis in summer is an example of a disease following seasonal 
trend. Seasonal trend is a type of periodic fluctuation. It refers to the occurrence of a disease in seasonal 
variation influenced by environmental conditions like climate, rainfall, life cycle of vectors, heat, 
etc. Examples are: • Measles and varicella in early spring • Bacterial gastroenteritis in summer • Heatstroke in summer 89 
Sold by @itachibot • Dengue in July-November • Respiratory infections in winter.

questions.question:
Question 12: The influenza pandemic is anticipated to occur every 7-10 years due to the antigenic variation 
of the virus. What is this an example of?
questions.explanation:
The influenza pandemic occuring every 7–10 years due to antigenic variations of the virus is an 
example of a disease showing cyclical trend. Diseases occurring in cycles spread over a short period of time show cyclical trends of time 
distribution. Cyclical trend is a type of periodic fluctuation. Examples include: • Measles: every 2-3 years in the pre-vaccination era. • Rubella: 6-9 years in the pre-vaccination era. Non-infectious conditions can also show cyclical trends.

questions.question: Question 13: How often did the cyclical trends of measles occured in the pre-vaccination era?
questions.explanation:
In the pre-vaccination era, the cyclical trends of measles occurred every 2-3 years, while that of 
rubella occurred every 6-9 years.

questions.question: Question 14: What is known as the change in the occurrence of a disease over very long periods of time?
questions.explanation:
A secular trend refers to the changes in the occurrence of a disease over long periods of time 
(decade). Usually, disease distributions tend to move in one particular direction over a period of time. 
Examples: Decrease in diseases like polio, tuberculosis, and typhoid fever, but increase in diabetes 
and coronary artery disease in developed countries.

questions.question: Question 15: Which of the following cannot be depicted by the image given below?

options.b: Rural - urban distributions of a disease

questions.explanation:
The given image is of a spot map. Spot maps are not used to depict rural-urban distributions of a 
disease. They help to understand the local distributions of a disease. They are also called shaded maps. This method was used by John Snow to investigate the 
epidemic of cholera in London in 1854. They depict areas of high or low frequency, the 
boundaries, and patterns of disease distribution. 90 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 16: What are migration studies used to evaluate?

options.a: Socio-demographic reasons for migration of a population
options.b: Prevalence of diseases in a population
options.c: Environmental and genetic factors of a disease in a population
options.d: Incidence of disease in the immigrant population

questions.explanation:
Migration studies are used to evaluate the role of genetic and environmental factors of a disease in 
a population. The two methods used are: • Comparing disease and death rates of migrants with kin who stayed at home • Comparing disease and death rates of migrants with the local population of the host country Limitations of these studies: • Non-randomization of these groups • Environmental factors may act only up to a certain age • Not useful for diseases with long incubation periods

questions.question: Question 17: What does bimodality in person distribution refer to?
questions.explanation:
Bimodality refers to the occurence two separate peaks in the age incidence curve of a disease. Example: Hodgkin's lymphoma shows a bimodal curve with peaks at 15–20 years and 70–80
